text: - Episode one is
It's about change.

Tray Barker has been
incarcerated for 15 years

for selling crack in
his own community.

He got a second chance
that he will do it right.
Walker, are you ready?

It's time for me to
go out to the world
and make it a better place.

When Tray Barker
gets out of prison

and he comes back to Brooklyn
and everything's changed.

You know, he come home
to a different world.
Honey, have some seaweed.
Seaweed is alkalizing.

What the [muted]
happened in Brooklyn?
Brooklyn.

The Brooklyn today is
different than the Brooklyn

that I know, because
it's gentrified.

It's better in some ways, but
then it's worse in some ways,

because you'll need to find
a lot of dudes got displaced.

But it's better, too,
because now my grandma
can walk down the street.

I feel like Rip van Winkle
in this mother-f , and I
don't even know who he is.

I think I'm coming home
to get my shorty back.
There she is.
Oh, she got a roommate.
No, a white dude?

When I came up with
the character of Shay,

I was listening to
Michael Jackson's song,
"She's Out of my Life."
He don't possess Shay.
Love is not possession.

He coming out of
jail, that's my girl.
No, it ain't.
You blew that, homie.

Fifteen years you've
been out of my life.

You think you've
just going to be
able to walk right back in it?

When Tray seen those kids,
he knew they were his.

You know if that's
your baby as a man.

I don't care what nobody say.
Amira knew it.

When she looked at me saw
me, that connection is there.
The blood talks, baby.

How did you and a Caucasian
man make two kids who last name
could be Wesley and Snipes?

He got to find out he is in
this new world that he's in now.
You got to wait and see, baby.
You've got to wait and see.
ANNOUNCER: "The Last O.G."

Catch up on demand
on the TBS app.
